item.title: Toxoplasma Motility 1
item.description: T. gondii tachyzoites were prelabeled with a fluorescent monoclonal antibody against the major GPI-linked surface protein, SAG1, added to glass coverslips precoated with bovine serum albumin and warmed to 35oC. As the parasite underwent circular gliding, the trail of fluorescent antibody deposited at its posterior end was recorded using a Dage VE1000SIT camera mounted on a Nikon Eclipse E400 microscope. The sequence is played back in real time; parasite is ~7um long.

item.title: Toxoplasma Motility 2
item.description: T. gondii tachyzoites were added to glass coverslips precoated with bovine serum albumin and warmed on the microscope stage to 35oC. The three different types of tachyzoite motility as defined by Hakaanson, Sibley and colleagues (Mol Biol Cell 10: 3539), i.e., circular gliding, helical gliding and twirling, were visualized using Nomarski optics and captured using a Dage VE1000SIT camera mounted on a Nikon Eclipse E400 microscope. The sequence is played back in real time; parasites are ~7um long.

item.title: Toxoplasma 3D Motility 1
item.description:
RH strain Toxoplasma tachyzoites were resuspended in diluted Matrigel containing Hoechst 33342. Fluorescent parasite nuclei were imaged in a 402 um x 401 um x 40 um volume (1 um z-slices) every 0.88 s for 60 s by time-lapse fluorescence videomicroscopy. The parasites move in left-handed, corkscrew-like trajectories; one representative trajectory is highlighted in green. Video playback is set at 4.5x speed. Scale bar = 10 um.

For further details, see PMCID: PMC3906025 for details.

item.title: In vitro Motility 1
item.description: Recombinant T. gondii MyosinA was produced in insect cells, immunoaffinity purified and adsorbed to nitrocellulose-coated coverslips. TRITC-phalloidin labeled actin filaments were added to the immobilized motor complexes, and actin filament displacement in the presence of ATP was captured by videomicroscopy. Filament displacement is shown in real time. See PMCID: PMC4215259 for details.

item.title: Toxoplasma Invasion 1
item.description: Invasion of a T. gondii tachyzoite into a human foreskin fibroblast. Note the constriction in the parasite’s plasma membrane that moves from anterior to posterior as the parasite penetrates past the host plasma membrane and into the developing parasitophorous vacuole. Real time; filmed at 35oC using a Dage VE1000SIT camera mounted on a Nikon Eclipse E400 microscope (Nomarski optics). The parasites are ~7um long.

item.title: Host Cell Egress 1
item.description: Eight Toxoplasma gondii tachyzoites in a single parasitophorous vacuole were stimulated to egresss from the infected host cell by treatment with calcium ionophore (1 uM ionomycin) in DMEM containing 4 mM calcium.

item.title: Plasmodium Invasion 1
item.description: Plasmodium knowlesi merozoites were incubated with rhesus monkey erythrocytes at 37oC on the stage of a Zeiss Axiophot fluorescence microscope equipped with Nomarski optics. Invasion was recorded on a Westinghouse Model ETV 6006E low-light level video camera and digitized. The parasite is ~1um long. The captured sequence is played back here in real time.

item.title: Plasmodium Invasion 2
item.description: Plasmodium knowlesi merozoites were incubated with PKH26-labeled rhesus monkey erythrocytes at 37oC on the stage of a Zeiss Axiophot fluorescence microscope equipped with Nomarski optics. Invasion was recorded on a Westinghouse Model ETV 6006E low-light level video camera and digitized. The captured sequence is played back here in real time. The parasite is ~1um long. Note incorporation of PKH26, a non-exchanging, fluorescent lipophilic membrane probe, into the forming parasitophorous vacuole membrane (PVM). Quantification of fluorescence intensity demonstrated that the PVM is formed from host cell lipids (see Ward, MIller and Dvorak, J. Cell Sci [1993] 106, 237-248 for details).
